Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics and Impacts of Mesoscale Gravity Waves in the Moist Baroclinic Jet-Front Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research explores the fundamental dynamics of gravity waves and their interaction with moist convection and baroclinic waves. It will characterize the source, dynamics and impacts of the mesoscale gravity waves generated in the moist baroclinic jet-front systems through utilizing high-resolution simulations of idealized moist baroclinic waves along with analyzing real-case modeling and aircraft observations during past field campaigns. The major objectives of the research are following. (1) Investigate the characteristics, source, propagation and dynamics of gravity waves simulated in high-resolution simulations of idealized moist baroclinic waves, examine the similarities and differences of wave initiation and propagation between simulations with varying intensity of moist convection, understand the coupling and interactions of gravity waves with small-scale moist convection and large-scale background baroclinic waves, and assess the momentum/energy fluxes from these gravity waves and their impacts on the large-scale circulation. (2) Explore the role of gravity waves and balance adjustment in the upscale error energy transfer from small-scale convection to largescale baroclinic waves and the impacts on mesoscale predictability of moist baroclinic jet-front systems under both idealized experiments and real-data events. (3) Characterize the source, propagation, dynamics and impacts of mesoscale gravity waves in the extratropical uppertropospheric lower-stratospheric region through analyzing high-resolution aircraft measurements and numerical simulations during the 2008 Stratosphere-Troposphere Analyses of Regional Transport Experiment (START08), and quantitatively compare the momentum and energy fluxes estimated from aircraft and satellite observations with those calculated from model simulations.

Intellectual Merit:
Gravity waves are ubiquitous in the atmosphere and play a fundamental role in a wide variety of atmospheric processes that have important implications for tropospheric weather, stratospheric dynamics, ozone chemistry and the general circulation. They can transfer significant amounts of energy and momentum, initiate and organize convection, and produce atmospheric turbulence. The momentum transport and deposition by gravity waves have significant impacts on the general circulation of the atmosphere. A better knowledge of these processes demands a complete understanding of the mechanisms by which the gravity waves are generated, together with their characteristics, distribution and variability. Building on the progress and success on dry dynamics of gravity waves achieved under previous NSF supports, the ultimate goal of this project is to understand the dynamics and impacts of the mesoscale gravity waves generated by the tropospheric baroclinic jet-front systems and their interactions with moist convection.

Broader Impacts:
Better understanding of mesoscale gravity waves and their interaction with moist processes may lead to better understanding of the dynamics and improved forecasts of convective triggers and modulation as well as the associated severe weather. Better understanding of flow imbalance and mesoscale gravity waves may provide guidance on mesoscale data assimilation and mesoscale predictability. Better understanding of gravity wave processes may also lead to better parameterization of the energy and momentum transport between the troposphere and stratosphere by non-topographic and non-convective mesoscale gravity waves. This project will fund and train two graduate students. It will also foster research collaborations between the university and several leading research institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamics and Impacts of Mesoscale Gravity Waves in the Moist Baroclinic Jet-Front Systems 

 

Project Outcome Report

 

         The ultimate goal of the proposed research is to characterize the source, dynamics and impacts of the atmospheric gravity waves generated in the moist baroclinic jet-front systems through utilizing high-resolution simulations of idealized moist baroclinic waves along with analyzing real-case modeling and aircraft observations during past field campaigns. We seek to explore the fundamental dynamics of the gravity waves and their interaction with moist convection and baroclinic waves. We have made significant progress in all areas of proposed activities. The project has led to a total of 27 peer-reviewed journal/book publications, and more than 20 conference, workshop or invited-seminar presentations. It trains and supports two doctoral students, both of whom have successfully completed their degrees, and both of whom have received and accepted prestigious postdoctoral fellowships, one at Princeton University (joint with GFDL) and the other in Germany. The project also partially supported several visiting scholars. The project also provided critical support for the 2016 SPARC Gravity Wave Symposium, 5-year international gravity wave summit led by PI Zhang held successfully at the Penn State University Campus which drew more than 100 participants from 20+ countries including about half of them from the United States, some of whom was provided travel support though the supplemental NSF funding to this project.

 

         Major activities and findings of the project to date are detailed as following:

1. Design and perform high-resolution numerical simulations to examine the coupling and interaction of mesoscale gravity waves and convection in the moist baroclinic jet-front systems, and examine the dynamics and sensitivity to moisture content of the gravity waves in the moist jet-front system (Wei and Zhang 2014).

2. Trace gravity waves in moist baroclinic jet-front systems using two-dimensional spectral decomposition and four-dimensional time-dependent ray-tracing techniques, and investigate the source mechanisms and propagating wave characteristics of the simulated gravity waves, as well as their momentum transport along the ray (Wei and Zhang 2015).

3. Assess the wave-induced momentum fluxes and their impacts on the large-scale circulation through analyzing 3-D phase, wavelength and frequency characteristics using discrete Fourier transform, which provides key input parameters toward better parameterizations of non-orographic gravity waves associated with moist baroclinic jet-front systems.

4. Fundamental understanding on the predictability and error growth dynamics of moist baroclinic waves under varying baroclinic and convective instabilities, and with different initial perturbation amplitudes and scales (Zhang et al. 2017; Sun and Zhang 2016; Bei and Zhang 2014).

5. Examine the contributions of moist convection and internal gravity waves to building the atmospheric “-5/3” kinetic energy spectra.

6. Explore the intrinsic versus practical predictability of multi-scale weather and convectively-coupled tropical waves during the active phase of an MJO.

7. Further exploration of balance versus imbalance in the initiation of inertia-gravity waves generated within a dipole vortex and dry baroclinic jet (Plougonven and Zhang 2014).

8. Characterize the source, propagation, dynamics and impacts of mesoscale gravity waves in the extratropical Upper-Tropospheric Lower-Stratospheric (UTLS) region through analyzing high-resolution aircraft measurements during the Stratosphere-Troposphere Analyses of Regional Transport Experiment 2008 (START08) field experiment (Zhang et al. 2015).

9. Continuous examination of the effect of mountain-plains solenoids (MPS) and sea-breeze circulation on the initiation and propagation of convection on the downstream plains (Bao and Zhang 2013a,b, Qian et al. 2012, 2015; Sun and Zhang 2012; Bao et al. 2011; Y Zhang et al. 2014, 2017; Chen et al. 2016, 2017; Zhu et al. 2017).

10. Examine the dynamics and propagation of tropical gravity waves and their co-existence and interaction with the diurnal cycles and moist convection through both observational analysis and cloud-resolving simulations (Lane and Zhang 2011).

 

Journal Publications fully or partially sponsored by the current project referenced above can be found at the webpage: http://adapt.psu.edu/ZHANG/zhangpublication.html
